ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would definitely recommend Spanish 140 to another student, with a warning that this is a very time consuming class.

Take this class with this professor if you want to learn spanish. He is passionate, engaging, and phenomenal. I completely recommend this. It is a good amount of work, but its worth it to learn with a great professor.

I would recommend the course. It's a little bit more work than 130 but is not so difficult on exams. A lot of work in partners and a lot of assessments, but overall it was an interesting course. I learned a bunch.
It is a lot of work but fun. A lot of partner work as well.
spanish 140 is a great way to improve your Spanish skills. There is a lot of verbal and written practice. However, don't go into it unless you're ready for a challenge.
Great course to improve your spanish

If you have to take this class to fulfill your language requirement, taking it with Diaz is a fair option. However, if your knowledge of the grammar concepts reviewed in the class is slightly rusty, I would recommend considering other instructors. Diaz is not the most clear, at times.
L4 is an alright class. I wouldn't suggest it to another student who wasn't passionate about continuing Spanish because of how much of a heavy workload it is.
You will certainly improve in Spanish, but you get out of it what you put in.

Rote. If not a requirement, and the student really wants to learn, I think it would be effort better spent to try to find a way to go to a Spanish-speaking country and live there for a few months. Perhaps there's more variety among professors, but in my experience the Spanish department and this class are pretty stultifying. Language classes can be wildly fun and productive! Like a gym class with exercises and a strange assortment of students and the clear pursuit of a skill. How does this get turned into such a staid routine?
